'Aino AcktÃ©' (originally 'Achte'; 23 April 18768 August 1944) was a Finnish
soprano. She was the first international star of the Finnish opera scene after
Alma FohstrÃ¶m, and a groundbreaker for the domestic field. {{cite book |last=Macchi |first=Giuliano |title=Musicus
discologus: musiche e scritti per il 70. anno di Carlo Marinelli
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=o7kZAQAAIAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1997 |publisher=Monteleone |isbn=978-88-8027-029-4 |pages=219â228}}

AcktÃ© was born in Helsinki. Her parents were mezzo-soprano Emmy AchtÃ© (nÃ©e
StrÃ¶mer) {{cite book |last=Estlander |first=Bernhard
|title=Elva Ã¥rtionden ur Finlands historia ...
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0xJAAAAAIAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1919 |publisher=SÃ¶derstrÃ¶m & c:o |language=Swedish |page=251}} and
the conductor-composer Lorenz Nikolai AchtÃ©. Aino AcktÃ© married a doctor, Heikki
Renvall, in 1901 and gave birth to a daughter, Glory LeppÃ¤nen, the same
year. {{cite book |last1=Ekberg |first1=Henrik
|last2=RehnstrÃ¶m |first2=Vivi-Ann |title=Uppslagsverket Finland
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oWjjAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1983 |publisher=Schildt |language=Swedish |isbn=978-951-50-0296-9
|page=232}} Their son, Mies Reenkola, was born in 1908. {{cite book |last1=Ekberg |first1=Henrik |last2=RehnstrÃ¶m |first2=Vivi-Ann
|title=Uppslagsverket Finland 2 K-R
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oWjjAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1983 |publisher=Schildt |language=Swedish |isbn=978-951-50-0296-9
|page=618}}

The young AcktÃ© studied singing under her mother's tutelage until 1894 when she
entered the Paris Conservatory, studying under Edmond Duvernoy and Alfred
Girodet. Her debut at the Paris Grand Opera was in 1897 in [[Faust
(opera)|Faust]] {{cite book |last=Knaus
|first=Gabriella Hanke |title=Richard Strauss, Ernst von Schuch: ein
Briefwechsel |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cMIZAQAAIAAJ |accessdate=10
October 2010 |year=1999 |publisher=Henschel |language=German |isbn=978-3-89487-329-
5 |page=121}} and she was signed on for six years as a result.

In 1904 AcktÃ© was engaged by the New York Metropolitan Opera where she remained
until 1906. She created the title role of Richard Strauss's [[Salome
(opera)|Salome]] at its local premieres in Leipzig (1907) and London (1910). {{cite book |last1=Brockway |first1=Wallace
|last2=Weinstock |first2=Herbert |last3=Leslie |first3=George Clark |title=The
opera: a history of its creation and performance: 1600-1941
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=XH86AAAAIAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1941 |publisher=Simon and Schuster |page=422}} The Covent Garden
premiere was an enormous success and Strauss himself proclaimed AcktÃ© the "one
and only Salome". {{cite book |last1=MÃ¤kinen
|first1=Timo |last2=Pajamo |first2=Reijo |title=Ihminen musiikin valtakentÃ¤ssÃ¤
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=woAXAQAAIAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1979 |publisher=JyvÃ¤skylÃ¤n yliopisto |language=Finnish |isbn=978-951-678-166-
5 |page=219}} AcktÃ© considered the London performances her real
breakthrough.

In 1911, AcktÃ©, Oskar Merikanto, and Edvard Fazer founded the Kotimainen Ooppera
(renamed in 1914 Finnish Opera, and then in 1956 the Finnish National Opera).
She was to act as its director in 1938-39. {{cite
book |last1=Kutsch |first1=K. J. |last2=Riemens |first2=Leo
|title=UnvergÃ¤ngliche Stimmen |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Q94uAAAAIAAJ
|accessdate=10 October 2010 |year=1975 |publisher=Francke |language=German |isbn=978-3-7720-1145-
0 |page=10}}

After parting ways with the National Opera, AcktÃ© organized an international
Savonlinna Opera Festival beginning on 3 July 1912; {{cite book |last=Symington |first=Andy |title=Lonely
Planet Finland |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=SNatbAr2SFgC&pg=PA136
|accessdate=10 October 2010 |date=1 April 2009 |publisher=Lonely Planet |isbn=978-1-74104-771-
4 |page=136}} it was held 1912-14, 1916 and 1930.

Jean Sibelius dedicated his tone poem [[Luonnotar (Sibelius)|Luonnotar]] to
AcktÃ© and she premiered the work on 10 September 1913 at the Three Choirs
Festival in Gloucester, England. {{cite book |last=Goss
|first=Glenda Dawn |title=Sibelius: a composer's life and the awakening of
Finland |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=929lNk1fqXoC&pg=PA357
|accessdate=10 October 2010 |date=1 December 2009 |publisher=University of
Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-30477-9 |page=357}} She also sang in the
first performance of Luonnotar in Finland, in January 1914.

AcktÃ© ended her international travels in 1914 and returned to Finland, where she
gave her farewell performance in 1920. Her final public performances took place
at the Savonlinna Opera Festival in 1930.

AcktÃ©'s coterie included among others Albert Edelfelt, who painted a famous full
portrait of her in 1901. {{cite book
|last1=Saarikivi |first1=Sakari |last2=Niilonen |first2=Kerttu |last3=Ekelund
|first3=Hilding |title=Art in Finland
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=sKeRAAAAIAAJ |accessdate=10 October 2010
|year=1955 |publisher=KustannusosakeyhtiÃ¶ Otava |page=5}} She provided the
libretto for Aarre Merikanto's opera [[Juha (Merikanto)|Juha]].

She died of pancreatic cancer in Nummela, Vihti in August 1944.
